comments.commentBody:
In Bush vs Gore, Gore came across as sighing at Bush's stupidity. Which is elitist.

In this instance, Trump was flat out insulting Clinton. She would have come across as a wimp if she hadn't reacted to being insulted.

That is because we've not spent any money on our infrastructure because we spent 30 years focusing on cutting taxes for the rich, and then another 8 years digging out from the debacle that caused.   Trump is certainly not going to do anything to improve LAX.
Great stream of consciousness and somehow more coherent than anything Trump said!

I think hillary did great she stay calm and collective very prepared he definitely showed his true colors he talked bout the same thing he is a clown he a man child he was so uncomfortable standing there he was asked a question that he answer with the same answer all night he has no clue he a racist a hypocrite he weird he a thief he hires and marries with immigrant beauty queens what man says if he wasn't h hi s daughters father he date them he might have a lil money but has no class  who cares who is indorsing him he a clown playin politician he a man child she admitted she made a mistake he has never apologize to any body he has offended he dont care bout latinos  and no we are not all criminals or rapist in every race and country there's a bad apple

If we had kept a stable force in Iraq, as we should of regardless of what the Iraq regime wanted, because we were supplying them billions a year plus all of our military equipment and they were not up to the job, had the foresight to deal with Erdogan, we would not of had them in Syria, period.  Yes, we would of had Boko Haram, which we should of dealt with immediately the week of the April 14th. abduction of the girls, and better leant ground troops in Somalia for helping that government, with Al Shabaab, need we mention how in 5 years, Clinton as secretary of State and President Obama were not able to work with NATO to deal with Assad, then what but chaos and death exists as the norm?
I find it sad that no one feels that giving intelligent answers is not worth assessing a Presidential debate.

The farce element of this debate only materializes because Donald Trump is involved. Hillary Clinton competed against Barack Obama 8 years ago and no one called that performance farcical. Perhaps misspoken and 'reaching', but never a farce. Now she is competing against a man who won't even say her name during the debate, referring to Hillary as "her" or "she". How anyone can see in Donald Trump a President of the United States is the ultimate farce, a question that has not applied to Hillary Clinton, whether you "like her" or not.
re the unmasking -- maybe so, but it seems a frightening swath of america doesn't perceive as much or, worse, likes what it sees

And here again we have false equivalency.

Trump displays his best medley of tourettes and paranoia, and Hillary is accused of Gore-esque sighs.

Please Arthur, your deplorables are immune to intellectual insult. We are not.

I think for the most part the people who have decided to vote for either candidate will stick with the decisions. I do think there might be a small percent that go from one to the other to undecided to maybe not voting at all. However, overall..I don't see the debate really changing the core supporters or the near outside supporters. If anything I'm convinced just not to go vote. I dislike both candidates...a lot.

J.D. Vance: Trump won the Republican debates because the policy prescriptions of his opponents were tired and discredited, and showed contempt for working class people. Why not admit it? Clinton raised the level of discourse, and the bar. She invited everyone to join her vision of America. Posturing as an outsider and strongman wont be enough this time around.

This is your second comment mentioning false and smug smiles, Majortrout. Clearly your mind is already made up. People who have decided between these candidates already didn't see anything that would make them change their minds tonight. But for the undecided, she had a lot more substantial things to say. Donald Trump repeated himself so much it started to sound like a tic, and he tried to interrrupt and bulldoze his way over his time limits, both with Clinton and with the moderator Lester Holt.

I couldn't believe that Trump blew the opportunity with his biggest "show" yet to act presidential and persuade the undecided that he wasn't just a crazy racist. He seemed unhinged and defensive and rude. For a man who proclaims his greatness as a negotiator
Trump blew the deal. I guess he just couldn't resist being the character "Trump" that his supporters love. Or, this Trump we saw tonight is the guy he really is, a madman who is totally unfit to be anywhere near the Oval Office.

Why would any thinking person even bring up Clinton's "false and smug smiles"? This and all the sexist desire to have her be more likeable. Voting for likable is what made a mess of America at home and abroad. Trump's repeated talking over of Clinton and Holt were almost to the point where his boorishness had me feeling sorry for him. Here was a man lowing, yes, lowing into the microphone "wrong" as if he were auditioning to be a fog horn.

Actually, it was Trumpmwho made a very loud and audible sigh.  I know you feel compelled to scrape for some false equivalency, but she was remarkably poised and gracious under the circumstances.  He was a sniffing, sighing, at times incoherent mess.
I dont think its like that with most Americans. I think most people in America are infected with selfishness and the people that get elected show it.

Did we see the same debate?  I saw Ms. Clinton, the 'smart girl in the class', strongly and objectively posit a number of positions to strengthen us internally in the US, and to position us strongly with our global partners and adversaries.  (And Mr. Trump repeatedly stumbled with no substance whatsover.)  There's no 'girl in the class' here--just an incredibly capable applicant to lead our nation forward with incredible experience.  Please get over the 'girl' part.  Looking forward to the next four years of our country getting over the 'girl' part, personally.
Absolutely disagree with your assessment.  She comported herself with style, humor, intelligence and restraint. DT went on a paranoid rant.

Often times the bully gets a bounce from these debates. You can win the debate and still come off as a less-than-vital policy hound who is too prepared. This is more of a "showing" than a debate, and most people are more interested in bravado and intimidation than they are in policies. It hurt Gore when he debated with Bush, and it's going to really hurt Clinton. In a college classroom, she's would have done well. But in front of a national audience who may or may not be paying attention to what is said, her body language didn't present anything charismatic, and, unfortunately, that reptilian part of the American brain makes the decisions for us quite a bit, no matter how aptly someone debates.
Short and easy!!  I thought he'd never shut up on some of those answers.  It was really funny when Clinton responded with a weary, mischievous, "whew"!

The debate was between a seasoned, emotionless, teacher-like politician, and an outsider who wants to shake the system. Recently, I have read the article "Intellectuay, Yet Stupid" by Nassim Taleb. It is a must read if one wants to understand why Trump's numbers will go up. Trump is a genius in persuasion. His statements are short and easy to remember. It is a completely open race. Time will tell.

Trump is being judged as if he was not a disturbed man. Read the transcript, watch it again with the sound off. It is not an issue of preparation. He is an ignorant, uneducable, psychologically disturbed man. He thinks in tweets: he couldn't look at a map and tell anyone where Iran is, where is Iraq is, where Afghanistan is, where Syria is; or how is the Constitution amended, what is the role of the Majority Leader of the Senate--Trump can't answer any of these questions. Stamina? What does that mean? He demonstrated he has neither physical nor mental stamina. The last thirty to forty-five minutes the guy was reduced to an incomprehensible, ignorant man who could talk about nothing but himself. He had no self-control; he was clearly out of his league and had no clue what he was doing on stage. I could go on, but he is finished. He has no idea of what it means to be president. Donald, you are a loser, you have no sense of who you are : to leap from that vacuous position to the demands of the presidency is beyond your comprehension.

I disagree. By allowing Trump to foam at the mouth like a rabid dog, both Clinton and Holt let him go into a free fall. He sounded ridiculous. If you try to challenge him too much, he can be quite tricky in turning an argument against you even when he is lying. This debate was kind of like the Ali rope-a-dope. Could Clinton have been more subatantive? Yes,  but she needed to win and these debates are often less about the issues than who has command of the room and the tactics he or she uses to maintain that edge. Clinton let the blowhard huff and puff until he was gasping to make sense.
Bernie is too busy acting like an adult who understands what is at stake on November 8.

Lester was next to useless.  The candidates were both boringly, predictably, true to form.  Few, if any, minds were changed.  Neither  of them "won" or "lost", although we did, as usual.  Where's Bernie when we really need him?

A debate with only half the candidates makes for a rigged election. The DNC primary was rigged, and corporate mass media rigs all mainstream discourse, by only allowing some ideas to be taken seriously, while the truth is derided as conspiracy theories and crazy talk.
The oil companies have known since the 70's that global warming would be a consequence of their business model, but it took 4 decades for corporate mass media to treat it seriously.
If Jill Stein was on the stage, she could have given good answers, while Trump ranted incoherently and Clinton tried to run from her record.
The only thing that the Democrats and Republicans agree on is making sure policy is dominated by global corporations.

It is an interesting issue.  Mrs Clinton needed to rise above the bar set for her and Mr Trump just needed to hit it.  In this instance I would say that she emerged the victor.  Arthur Brooks wrote a piece about Gore's infamous sighs and how Mrs Clintons performance was on par.  To that I would say that we were obviously  watching two different channels or , god forbid, he is holding Mrs Clinton to a different standard than other male candidates.  I was perfectly pleased that her face remained calm and passive.  There were points toward the end when Mr Trump was going on about birthism that she looked ready to pounce that I turned to my friends and said, "that is the face that an anti Hillary person will love" but she also reminded me of my own parents/grandparents in that calm collective expression that is letting you have your say before calmly explaining that there may be more to an issue than you are aware BUT it is still worth the time to let you have your say.  There is no "sigh or checking your watch" moment and if there was I would calmly and nicely say to Mr Brooks that he should have been paying as much attention to the disengaged, petulant, and bored face of Mr Trump instead of looking for what everyone was afraid would happen, the informed person condescending to the uniformed person in Mrs Clinton which did show up in Mr Trump.  To that point though, it may be to whom we believe will be the best president.

Oh please, a bias against Trump? The man who kept the birther thing going, who cheats people, who lies so much and so often his entire  genome should be sequnced and his brain studied to find out if narcissistic disorders have a genetic existence. Trump earns the journalistic coverage he gets.

I questioned her lack of response to personal attacks as well but left the whole thing wondering if it was not the smarter move to just pass them by.  A sort of why bother.  I am sure we can debate on whether the public deserves an answer but on the same front I can also see this dialogue chain being taken up by Clinton spending too much time defending against attacks, many of which are just unfounded.  How does one defend against accusations?  In many of these cases it is not innocent until proven guilty, it is guilty until you come up with a better answer.  Not the best use of time to get your message out maybe?
The Clinton foundation has an A rating from independent watch groups.
